questions.text: One of the following opens in the middle meatus of the nose:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Maxillary air sinus. The maxillary sinus, one of the paranasal sinuses, opens into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity. This is an important anatomical feature because the middle meatus is the location where the drainage of several sinuses occurs, including the maxillary sinus. When the sinus is infected or inflamed, it can cause symptoms such as facial pain or pressure. Incorrect Responses: A. Naso-lacrimal duct The naso-lacrimal duct drains tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity, but it opens into the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity, not the middle meatus. Therefore, this option is incorrect. B. Eustachian tube The Eustachian tube, also known as the auditory tube, connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx. It opens into the nasopharynx rather than the nasal cavity, so it does not drain into the middle meatus. Hence, this is not the correct answer. C. Sphenoidal air sinus The sphenoidal sinus opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which is located above the superior meatus of the nasal cavity, not the middle meatus. Therefore, the sphenoidal sinus is not the correct answer.

questions.text: Safety muscle of larynx:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Posterior cricoarytenoid The posterior cricoarytenoid is considered the "safety muscle" of the larynx because it is the only muscle that opens the vocal cords. It functions to abduct the vocal cords, allowing air to pass through the trachea and into the lungs. This muscle is crucial in maintaining a patent airway, especially during breathing. If the posterior cricoarytenoid is paralyzed, the vocal cords cannot be fully abducted, potentially causing respiratory distress or airway obstruction, making it a critical muscle for protecting the airway. Incorrect Answers: A. Lateral cricoarytenoid The lateral cricoarytenoid muscle is responsible for adducting (closing) the vocal cords, which is important for phonation and protecting the airway during swallowing. However, it does not play a role in maintaining an open airway, which is why it is not considered the "safety muscle" of the larynx. It helps in vocal cord closure but does not directly ensure airway patency like the posterior cricoarytenoid. B. Transverse arytenoid The transverse arytenoid muscle also functions to adduct the vocal cords, contributing to vocal cord closure during phonation. Similar to the lateral cricoarytenoid, it plays a role in vocal cord closure but does not aid in airway opening. Thus, it cannot be considered the safety muscle since it does not prevent airway obstruction in the same way the posterior cricoarytenoid does. D. Cricothyroids The cricothyroid muscles are responsible for tensioning the vocal cords, which alters pitch during speech. They are involved in vocal cord modulation but do not directly impact the opening or closing of the airway. Although they are essential for phonation, they do not have a direct role in ensuring the safety of the airway, making them less crucial for maintaining a clear and open airway compared to the posterior cricoarytenoid.

questions.text: Which part of the ear has origin from all the three layer of germ layer :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tympanic membrane The tympanic membrane (eardrum) is derived from all three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. The outer layer of the tympanic membrane originates from the ectoderm, the middle layer (the fibrous layer) comes from mesoderm, and the inner layer (the mucous membrane) is derived from endoderm. This makes the tympanic membrane a structure with contributions from all three embryonic germ layers. Incorrect Answers: A. Auricle The auricle (or pinna) is primarily derived from the 1st and 2nd branchial arches. The outer parts, including the skin, are derived from the ectoderm, while the cartilage comes from mesoderm. However, the auricle does not have contributions from all three germ layers, making this option incorrect. C. Ossicles The ossicles (malleus, incus, and stapes) are derived from the mesoderm, specifically from the first and second pharyngeal arches. While these structures are important for hearing, they are not derived from all three germ layers. Therefore, this option is incorrect. D. Middle ear cavity The middle ear cavity is derived from the pharyngeal pouches, which are endodermal in origin. However, it does not involve all three germ layers, as it is primarily endodermal in origin with no ectodermal or mesodermal contributions to its structure.

questions.text: The lacrimal duct open in the
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Inferior meatus. The lacrimal duct, specifically the nasolacrimal duct, opens into the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity. This duct is responsible for draining tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity. The inferior meatus is located beneath the inferior turbinate, and it serves as the passage for the nasolacrimal duct, allowing for the drainage of excess tears. This anatomical feature plays a crucial role in tear drainage and preventing tears from pooling in the eye. Incorrect Options: A. Superior turbinate: The superior turbinate is located in the upper part of the nasal cavity, and it is not involved in the drainage of the lacrimal duct. The superior turbinate is associated with the upper meatus and is related to the airflow and the sinuses, not the lacrimal drainage. B. Middle meatus: The middle meatus is located between the middle turbinate and inferior turbinate. It is the region where the frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoidal sinuses drain. It does not receive drainage from the lacrimal duct, which opens into the inferior meatus instead. D. None of the above: Since the lacrimal duct does indeed open into the inferior meatus, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Sensory nerve supply of middle ear cavity is provided by-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Glossopharyngeal. The sensory nerve supply of the middle ear cavity is provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX). Specifically, the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, also known as the Jacobsen's nerve, enters the middle ear through the tympanic canaliculus. This nerve provides sensation to the mucosa of the middle ear, including the tympanic membrane and the Eustachian tube. The glossopharyngeal nerve is the primary sensory nerve responsible for the sensation in this area. Incorrect Options: A. Facial: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) primarily provides motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression and some sensory functions, but it does not provide sensory innervation to the middle ear cavity. Instead, the facial nerve gives off a small branch, the chorda tympani, which passes through the middle ear but is responsible for taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, not sensory input from the middle ear. C. Vagus: The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) does contribute to the sensory supply in the ear, particularly the external ear and ear canal, but it is not the primary nerve supplying the middle ear. The vagus nerve provides sensory innervation to the ear and parts of the larynx and pharynx, but it does not primarily innervate the middle ear cavity. D. Trigeminal: The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) provides sensory innervation to the face, including the skin and mucosa of the nasal cavity, but it does not supply the middle ear. The trigeminal nerve’s mandibular branch (V3) gives sensation to the external ear canal but does not innervate the middle ear cavity itself.

questions.text: Inner ear is present in which bone
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Petrous part of temporal bone. The inner ear is located within the petrous part of the temporal bone. This part of the temporal bone houses the cochlea, vestibule, and semicircular canals, which are responsible for hearing and balance. The petrous bone is the dense, hard portion of the temporal bone that provides protection to these delicate structures. It contains the bony labyrinth, which encases the sensory organs of the inner ear, making it the correct location for the inner ear. Incorrect Options: A. Occipital: The occipital bone forms the back and base of the skull and does not house the inner ear. It is involved in the formation of the foramen magnum and provides structural support for the brainstem and spinal cord, but it does not contain the auditory or vestibular structures. C. Squamous part of temporal: The squamous part of the temporal bone is located laterally and forms part of the side of the skull. While it is involved in the structure of the middle ear, it does not house the inner ear. The inner ear is located in the petrous part of the temporal bone, not the squamous part. D. Parietal bone: The parietal bones form the top and sides of the skull and do not contain the inner ear. The parietal bones are primarily involved in protecting the brain and do not house any of the structures related to hearing or balance.

questions.text: Throat pain radiating to the ear following tonsillectomy is due to-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Injury to IX nerve. The pain radiating to the ear following tonsillectomy is most commonly due to injury or irritation of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX). The glossopharyngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the mucosa of the oropharynx, including the tonsils, and its branches, such as the tympanic nerve, carry pain sensations. The tonsils are located near areas where the glossopharyngeal nerve is distributed, so trauma during tonsillectomy can lead to referred pain, often perceived in the ear due to the nerve's anatomical distribution. This phenomenon is known as referred pain and is typically observed as otalgia (ear pain) following tonsillectomy. Incorrect Options: A. Persistent infection: Persistent infection could cause ongoing pain, but it would usually present with symptoms such as fever, swelling, and redness, rather than the characteristic referred pain to the ear. In the case of post-tonsillectomy pain radiating to the ear, it is more likely a result of nerve injury rather than infection. C. Injury to X nerve: The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) is involved in motor control of the soft palate and pharynx and has some sensory functions in the larynx and pharynx. However, injury to the vagus nerve is less likely to cause referred pain to the ear after tonsillectomy. The glossopharyngeal nerve (IX) is the primary nerve involved in sensory innervation of the tonsils, making vagus nerve injury an unlikely cause of ear pain. D. Injury to Eustachian tube: While damage to the Eustachian tube can lead to issues such as ear congestion or middle ear infections, it is not typically the cause of referred throat pain following tonsillectomy. The Eustachian tube does not have the same role in mediating pain sensations as the glossopharyngeal nerve does.

questions.text: Internal laryngeal nerve supplies
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mucous membrane above vocal fold The internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (itself a branch of the vagus nerve), primarily innervates the mucous membrane above the vocal folds. It is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the epiglottis, the aryepiglottic folds, and the supraglottic area (above the vocal folds). Therefore, the correct answer is C. Incorrect Answers: A. Cricothyroid muscle The cricothyroid muscle is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, not the internal laryngeal nerve. The internal laryngeal nerve does not supply motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle. Therefore, option A is incorrect. B. Vocalis The vocalis muscle, which controls the tension of the vocal cords, is innervated by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, not the internal laryngeal nerve. Thus, the internal laryngeal nerve does not supply the vocalis muscle, making option B incorrect. D. Mucous membrane below vocal fold The mucous membrane below the vocal folds is innervated by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, which provides sensory innervation to the infraglottic region (below the vocal folds). Therefore, option D is incorrect, as this region is not supplied by the internal laryngeal nerve.

choices.text: The opening of the auditory tube is located in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx
The soft palate is at the level of separation of the laryngopharynx and the oropharynx
The pharynx is continuous with the esophagus at the level of the Seventh cervical vertebra
The afferent limb of the gag reflex is cranial nerve X; the efferent limb is cranial nerve IX

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the pharynx is/are correct
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The opening of the auditory tube is located in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx The opening of the auditory tube (also known as the Eustachian tube) is located in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx. This tube connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx, helping equalize air pressure in the middle ear. Therefore, option A is correct. Incorrect Answers: B. The soft palate is at the level of separation of the laryngopharynx and the oropharynx This statement is incorrect because the soft palate is located at the boundary between the nasopharynx and the oropharynx, not at the level of the separation between the oropharynx and the laryngopharynx. The separation between the oropharynx and the laryngopharynx is at the level of the epiglottis, which is lower than the level of the soft palate. Hence, option B is incorrect. C. The pharynx is continuous with the esophagus at the level of the seventh cervical vertebra This statement is incorrect. The pharynx transitions into the esophagus at the level of the sixth cervical vertebra (C6), not C7. At the C6 level, the laryngopharynx connects to the esophagus, while the cricoid cartilage marks this junction. Therefore, option C is incorrect. D. The afferent limb of the gag reflex is cranial nerve X; the efferent limb is cranial nerve IX This statement is incorrect. The afferent limb of the gag reflex is carried by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), while the efferent limb is carried by the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X). This reflex involves both sensory (CN IX) and motor (CN X) components, so the roles are reversed in this option.

questions.text: The only pharyngeal muscle innervated by the glosspharyngeal nerve is the -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Stylopharyngeus. Explanation: Correct Answer: (A) Stylopharyngeus: The stylopharyngeus muscle is the only pharyngeal muscle innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX). This muscle plays a role in elevating the pharynx and larynx during swallowing and speaking. The glossopharyngeal nerve provides motor innervation to this muscle, making it the unique muscle in the pharynx with this specific nerve supply. Incorrect Answers: (B) Palatopharyngeus: The palatopharyngeus muscle is innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X), not the glossopharyngeal nerve. It helps elevate the pharynx and larynx during swallowing. (C) Superior constrictor: The superior constrictor muscle is also innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X), not the glossopharyngeal nerve. It is part of the muscle group responsible for constricting the pharynx during swallowing. (D) Middle constrictor: Like the superior constrictor, the middle constrictor is innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X) and is involved in the constriction of the pharynx during the process of swallowing.

questions.text: The tip of the nose is supplied by -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ophthalmic N.. Explanation: The tip of the nose is supplied by the ophthalmic nerve, which is the first branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V). Specifically, the external nasal branch of the anterior ethmoidal nerve (a branch of the ophthalmic nerve) provides sensory innervation to the tip of the nose. This area, including the skin at the tip, is innervated by the ophthalmic nerve, making it responsible for the general sensation in that region. Incorrect responses: A. Maxillary N.: The maxillary nerve is the second division of the trigeminal nerve. It supplies sensory innervation to the midface, including the upper lip, cheek, nasal cavity (lateral side), and the maxillary teeth. However, it does not supply the tip of the nose, which is innervated by the ophthalmic nerve. B. Mandibular N.: The mandibular nerve is the third division of the trigeminal nerve. It provides sensory innervation to the lower jaw, lower lip, chin, and parts of the ear. It also provides motor innervation to the muscles of mastication. However, it does not innervate the nose, particularly the tip. D. Facial N.: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is primarily a motor nerve responsible for the muscles of facial expression. It does not contribute to the sensory innervation of the tip of the nose. The sensory function of the tip of the nose is carried out by the ophthalmic nerve, not the facial nerve.

questions.text: Which is not a content of tympanic cavity-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Post. auricular N. Explanation: The tympanic cavity (also known as the middle ear) contains several important structures related to hearing and innervation, but the posterior auricular nerve (a branch of the facial nerve) is not one of them. The posterior auricular nerve primarily supplies the muscles around the ear and certain sensory regions of the ear, but it does not pass through or have any direct connection with the tympanic cavity. Incorrect responses: A. Malleus: The malleus is one of the three auditory ossicles located in the tympanic cavity. It is connected to the tympanic membrane (eardrum) and transmits vibrations from the eardrum to the other ossicles, playing a critical role in hearing. It is a key content of the tympanic cavity. B. Chorda tympani: The chorda tympani is a branch of the facial nerve that passes through the tympanic cavity. It carries parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular and sublingual glands and also taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It travels through the tympanic cavity, running along the malleus. C. Stapedius: The stapedius muscle is located within the tympanic cavity. It is attached to the stapes (the third auditory ossicle) and helps control the amplitude of sound vibrations by damping the movement of the stapes. This is important for protecting the inner ear from loud sounds.

questions.text: Alderman’s nerve is -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Auricular branch of Vagus nerve. Explanation: Alderman’s nerve, also known as the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (or Arnold’s nerve), is a sensory branch of the vagus nerve (CN X). It provides sensation to the external ear canal and the auricle (outer ear). This nerve also contributes to the sensory innervation of the tympanic membrane (eardrum). Therefore, the correct answer is C, as it is indeed a branch of the vagus nerve. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Branch of Superior cervical ganglion The superior cervical ganglion is part of the sympathetic nervous system and gives rise to several branches that innervate structures like blood vessels and the eye, but it does not give rise to Alderman’s nerve. This option is incorrect because the auricular nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve, not the sympathetic ganglion. B. Branch of Inferior cervical ganglion The inferior cervical ganglion is involved in sympathetic innervation, mainly contributing to the brachial plexus and some structures in the neck and upper limbs. It does not give rise to Alderman’s nerve. Therefore, this option is also incorrect. D. Tympanic branch of Glossopharyngeal nerve The tympanic branch (also known as Jacobson's nerve) is a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) and provides parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland and sensory innervation to the middle ear and Eustachian tube. However, this is not related to Alderman's nerve. Alderman’s nerve is derived from the vagus nerve, not the glossopharyngeal nerve.

choices.text: Pharyngeal branch from superior cervical sympathetic ganglion

questions.text: Tympanic plexus is formed by all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mandibular nerve. Explanation: The tympanic plexus is a network of nerves located in the middle ear cavity, primarily responsible for innervating the ear and structures related to it. The plexus is formed by contributions from several sources, but the mandibular nerve is not one of them. Why the other options are correct: A. Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve The tympanic branch (also called the Jacobsen's nerve) is one of the main contributors to the tympanic plexus. It carries parasympathetic and sensory fibers from the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) and provides the majority of the innervation to the tympanic plexus. It is responsible for innervating the middle ear and parts of the Eustachian tube. B. Vagus nerve The vagus nerve (CN X) also contributes to the tympanic plexus, providing autonomic fibers to the middle ear. It sends a small branch that joins the tympanic plexus and helps in innervating structures such as the muscles of the tympanic membrane and the pharynx. C. Pharyngeal branch from superior cervical sympathetic ganglion The superior cervical sympathetic ganglion sends a pharyngeal branch to the tympanic plexus, contributing sympathetic fibers. These sympathetic fibers help regulate the blood vessels in the middle ear and the Eustachian tube. This branch is a part of the autonomic innervation to the region.

questions.text: Nasolacrimal duct is directed –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Downward, laterally, backwards. Explanation: The nasolacrimal duct is directed downward, laterally, and backward as it travels from the lacrimal sac to the nasal cavity. The duct originates at the lacrimal sac, passes through the nasolacrimal canal, and opens into the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity. The duct's course allows it to drain tears from the eye into the nose, and its direction is important in understanding the anatomy of tear drainage. Why the other options are incorrect: Downward, medially, backwards (Option A) This option is incorrect because the nasolacrimal duct does not course medially. It runs laterally as it travels toward the nasal cavity. The medial direction would be incorrect as it would imply the duct is heading towards the midline, which is not the case. Downward, laterally, forward (Option C) This option is incorrect because the nasolacrimal duct does not travel forward. The duct moves backward toward the posterior aspect of the nasal cavity rather than forward. The forward direction would place it incorrectly in relation to the nasal and lacrimal structures. Downward, medially, forward (Option D) This option is also incorrect because, as mentioned above, the nasolacrimal duct does not travel medially or forward. The correct direction is lateral and backward, not medially and forward.

choices.text: Berry ligament arises from deep cervical fascia
Thyroid enclosed between 2 layers of deep cervical fascia
Longer course of recurrent laryngeal nerve on left than right
Superior thyroid artery related closely to external laryngeal nerve

questions.text: True regarding surgical anatomy of thyroid gland is all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Thyroid enclosed between 2 layers of deep cervical fascia. Explanation: The thyroid gland is not enclosed between two layers of the deep cervical fascia. Instead, it is located within the pretracheal fascia, which is a layer of the deep cervical fascia. The pretracheal fascia surrounds the thyroid gland and provides support. The gland is also related to the trachea and esophagus. The misconception in Option B arises from the idea that the thyroid is enclosed by two layers of the deep cervical fascia, which is not anatomically correct. Why the other options are correct: Berry ligament arises from deep cervical fascia (Option A) The Berry ligament is a connective tissue structure that anchors the thyroid gland to the trachea and larynx. It is an important surgical landmark and arises from the deep cervical fascia, specifically the pretracheal layer. It helps stabilize the thyroid gland in its position relative to the trachea and larynx. Longer course of recurrent laryngeal nerve on left than right (Option C) The recurrent laryngeal nerve on the left side takes a longer course because it loops around the aortic arch before ascending to the larynx, whereas the right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the right subclavian artery and has a shorter course. This anatomical difference is crucial for surgeons to be aware of when performing thyroid surgeries. Superior thyroid artery related closely to external laryngeal nerve (Option D) The superior thyroid artery is indeed closely related to the external laryngeal nerve. The external laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (from the vagus nerve), travels with the superior thyroid artery as they ascend to the thyroid gland. The close relationship between these two structures is important during thyroid surgeries to avoid injury to the nerve.

questions.text: Tensor tympani is supplied by -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mandibular branch of the 5th nerve. Explanation: The tensor tympani muscle is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V3). This muscle is located in the middle ear and functions to dampen sounds, particularly those associated with mastication, by pulling on the malleus and tensing the tympanic membrane. This action reduces the amplitude of vibrations to protect the inner ear from loud noises. The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve is the motor supply for the tensor tympani, along with other muscles like the tensor veli palatini and the muscles of mastication. Why the other options are incorrect: Maxillary branch of the 5th nerve (Option A) The maxillary branch (V2) of the trigeminal nerve is purely sensory and provides sensation to areas such as the maxilla, nasal cavity, and palate. It does not supply motor innervation to any muscles, including the tensor tympani, making this option incorrect. Facial nerve (Option C) The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) supplies the stapedius muscle in the middle ear, which functions to stabilize the stapes bone and also dampens sound vibrations. However, it does not innervate the tensor tympani. This distinction highlights the specialized roles of these cranial nerves in the middle ear. Lingual nerve (Option D) The lingual nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), but it is purely sensory and provides sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. While it is part of the mandibular branch, it has no role in the motor innervation of the tensor tympani.

questions.text: A Patient presents after Fracture at skull base and Doctor examined the marked area. Which nerve supplies the marked muscle and is involved in Gag reflex
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) X N. (Vagus Nerve).Explanation: The red arrow in the image points to the pharynx, which contains muscles essential for swallowing and the gag reflex. The gag reflex is a protective reflex with both a sensory (afferent) limb and a motor (efferent) limb. While the Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX N.) provides the primary sensory input from the pharynx, the Vagus nerve (X N.) is the main motor nerve that supplies most of the muscles of the pharynx, including the pharyngeal constrictors and palatal muscles responsible for the reflexive contractions seen in the gag reflex. Therefore, the Vagus nerve directly "supplies the marked muscle" (pharyngeal muscles) and executes the motor component of the gag reflex. Therefore, the answer is 10th nerve i.e,vagus nerve

questions.text: Identify the marked bone?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-The malleus is the 1st ossicle, attaching to and moving with the tympanic membrane. This ossicle has a head, neck, short process, and handle. Option B-The incus is the 2nd ossicle and has a body and short and long processes. This bone connects with the stapes and forms the incudostapedial joint. Option C-The stapes is the 3rd ossicle, consisting of a head, legs, and a footplate. This bone is the smallest in the human body. The stapes articulates with the inner ear's oval window. Option D-Talus is present in the foot.

questions.text: Which of the following marking represents Piriform Fossa
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-A is Epiglottis Option B-B is glottis present between two vocal cords. Option C-C is aryepiglottic fold Option D-D is pyriform fossa which is present lateral to aryepiglottic fold.Frequently,fish bone or foreign body gets stuck here.

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling under the left ear lobule and complains of pain. Which of the following structures is the likely cause of pain?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Facial nerve is associated with Hitzelberger sign which is the numbness of the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal. It is seen in acoustic neuroma and is not associated with swelling over the parotid region. Option B-The greater auricular nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin overlying the parotid gland and ear lobule. Option C-The auriculotemporal nerve can cause referred pain due to caries tooth or ulcerative lesions of the oral cavity. However it is not the primary cause of pain in parotid region due to swelling. Option D-Investing layer of deep cervical fascia itself does not transmit pain sensation.

questions.text: Find the correct matching for auricle nerve supply
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A is Greater auricular nerve. B is Auriculotemporal nerve. C is Vagus nerve. D is Lesser occipital nerve.
